articles.headline: Markets Fall as Lender Woes Keep Mounting
articles.snippet: Stocks tumbled on fears that worsening ills in the mortgage and debt markets could soon take a significant toll on the overall economy.
articles.abstract: Stocks tumbled on fears that worsening ills in the mortgage and debt markets could soon take a significant toll on the overall economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks tumbled yesterday on fears that the worsening ills in the mortgage and debt markets could soon take a significant toll on consumers, businesses and the overall economy.

articles.headline: Report Says S.E.C. Erred on Pequot
articles.snippet: A report by Congressional investigators says that the S.E.C. bungled a promising investigation two years ago into suspicious trading at Pequot Capital Management.
articles.abstract: A report by Congressional investigators says that the S.E.C. bungled a promising investigation two years ago into suspicious trading at Pequot Capital Management.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission bungled a promising investigation two years ago into suspicious trading at Pequot Capital Management, a giant hedge fund, according to the final report released yesterday by Congressional investigators looking into the matter.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Walt Bogdanich

articles.headline: States Across the Country Race to Inspect Bridges
articles.snippet: Officials were racing to inspect  bridges that are similar to the steel-deck truss bridge that collapsed in Minneapolis.
articles.abstract: Officials were racing to inspect  bridges that are similar to the steel-deck truss bridge that collapsed in Minneapolis.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 3 — As recovery divers moved from car to car in the murky waters of the Mississippi River on Friday, state officials across the country raced to inspect bridges that are similar to the steel-deck truss bridge that collapsed here, killing at least five people.

articles.headline: Slowly, Clinton Shifts on War, Quieting Foes
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who voted in 2002 to authorize the invasion of Iraq, has over the past year repositioned herself.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who voted in 2002 to authorize the invasion of Iraq, has over the past year repositioned herself.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 — A little more than a year ago, before Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton entered the race for the White House, she drew a storm of boos from an audience of liberal Democrats here as she declared that it would be a mistake to set a “date certain” for withdrawing American troops from Iraq.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: As the Vision Fades, the Indignities Grow
articles.snippet: Baby boomers are now groping for reading glasses to peruse menus in dim restaurants and to review the tiny instructions on medicine bottles.
articles.abstract: Baby boomers are now groping for reading glasses to peruse menus in dim restaurants and to review the tiny instructions on medicine bottles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert Masello used to laugh at his parents when he went out to eat with them. If the restaurant had a menu with pictures, his father would point to any vaguely appealing image. For his farsighted mother, Mr. Masello, in his teens at the time, would hold the menu up from across the table.

articles.headline: What’s Good for a Business Can Be Hard on Friends
articles.snippet: Cellphone plans that encourage subscribers to talk mainly to people in the same network are having unintentional social effects.
articles.abstract: Cellphone plans that encourage subscribers to talk mainly to people in the same network are having unintentional social effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: A month ago, Brandy McDowell sat down with her longtime friend, Kezia Chandler, and told her she had switched cellphone carriers. Their relationship has not been the same since.

articles.headline: Drug Gangs Use Violence to Sway Guatemala Vote
articles.snippet: Twenty-six people have been killed in 61 attacks on candidates and activists as national elections approach.
articles.abstract: Twenty-six people have been killed in 61 attacks on candidates and activists as national elections approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — It is election time in Guatemala and that means rallies and banners — and body bags.

articles.headline: Jobs Growth Slid in July, Echoing Drift
articles.snippet: The job market lost some of its punch in July as employers added 92,000 jobs — the fewest in five months — and unemployment edged up to 4.6 percent.
articles.abstract: The job market lost some of its punch in July as employers added 92,000 jobs — the fewest in five months — and unemployment edged up to 4.6 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Job creation slackened last month, extending a trend of softening employment growth that mirrors the modestly downward path of the economy.

articles.headline: A Family’s Benign Neglect at Dow Jones
articles.snippet: Some Bancrofts didn’t think that their family’s ownership of Dow Jones was ever going to be in the best interest of the company.
articles.abstract: Some Bancrofts didn’t think that their family’s ownership of Dow Jones was ever going to be in the best interest of the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: “The primary reason I was in favor of the deal,” said Elisabeth Goth Chelberg on Wednesday, “is because I did not think that family ownership was ever going to be in the best interest of the company.” She paused for a second, and then offered a small, sad correction. “I mean this family ownership.”

articles.headline: Drawing Fire, Judith Giuliani Gives Her Side
articles.snippet: “It’s a learning curve for me,” Mrs. Giuliani said of her inexperience as a political wife after a rocky rollout to the public.
articles.abstract: “It’s a learning curve for me,” Mrs. Giuliani said of her inexperience as a political wife after a rocky rollout to the public.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has not been an easy few months for Judith Giuliani. Her rollout to the public received rocky reviews from the political class, Republicans included. A series of negative articles about her shopping habits, marital past and supposedly testy relations with campaign staff followed. Her appearances alongside her husband, Rudolph W. Giuliani, grew suddenly scarce — and some analysts suggested that she keep it that way.

articles.headline: They’re All No. 1, but Are They Worth It?
articles.snippet: Having Goldman Sachs or Morgan Stanley in your corner may not always be the best choice.
articles.abstract: Having Goldman Sachs or Morgan Stanley in your corner may not always be the best choice.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON Wall Street, bragging rights are the coin of the realm, and money is the measure. Just as Hollywood studio heads watch box-office receipts to judge who’s on top, investment bankers anxiously wait to see who is No. 1 on so-called league tables, which rank banks based on the size of the deals they handle each quarter.

articles.headline: In Silicon Valley, Millionaires Who Don’t Feel Rich
articles.snippet: Many members of the digital elite do not see themselves as particularly fortunate, in part because others have more.
articles.abstract: Many members of the digital elite do not see themselves as particularly fortunate, in part because others have more.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — By almost any definition — except his own and perhaps those of his neighbors here in Silicon Valley — Hal Steger has made it.

articles.headline: Mortgage Mania Didn’t Grip Everyone
articles.snippet: Michael A. J. Farrell, chief executive of Annaly Capital Management, is an excellent person to consult on what is likely to happen next.
articles.abstract: Michael A. J. Farrell, chief executive of Annaly Capital Management, is an excellent person to consult on what is likely to happen next.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE seized-up United States mortgage market claimed more victims both here and abroad last week. The American Home Mortgage Investment Corporation, once a big lender, closed its doors, laying off more than 6,000 workers. In Germany, IKB Deutsche Industriebank received a $4.8 billion bailout from a government-owned group that said it would cover potential subprime losses at the bank.

articles.headline: The Katrina Effect, Measured in Gigs
articles.snippet: Fewer tourists in New Orleans means less money for musicians.
articles.abstract: Fewer tourists in New Orleans means less money for musicians.
articles.lead_paragraph: New Orleans

articles.headline: British Make Initial Gains Against Taliban
articles.snippet: Progress in Afghanistan’s most dangerous province is perhaps the most important in the country, officials say.
articles.abstract: Progress in Afghanistan’s most dangerous province is perhaps the most important in the country, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANGIN, Afghanistan — The British Army compound here in a drug lord’s former villa, with its sandbagged windows and lookout posts and shrapnel-scarred walls, is a reminder that until just a few weeks ago Sangin was one of the most dangerous towns in Afghanistan’s most dangerous province, Helmand.

articles.headline: Nothing to Watch on TV? Streaming Video Appeals to Niche Audiences
articles.snippet: The potential of new streaming video services is unleashing a torrent of programming aimed at narrowly defined audiences.
articles.abstract: The potential of new streaming video services is unleashing a torrent of programming aimed at narrowly defined audiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: Buffering ... buffering ... buffering.

articles.headline: Bid to Root Out Lead Trinkets Falters in U.S.
articles.snippet: Despite federal efforts to eliminate the threat of lead in children’s jewelry, hundreds of thousands of tainted items are still being sold across the country.
articles.abstract: Despite federal efforts to eliminate the threat of lead in children’s jewelry, hundreds of thousands of tainted items are still being sold across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 — Despite a two-year effort to eliminate the threat of poisonous lead in inexpensive children’s jewelry, hundreds of thousands of tainted items are still being sold across the United States, the federal government has found.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Louise Story

articles.headline: It’s an Ad, Ad, Ad, Ad World
articles.snippet: Hoping to deliver personalized messages to consumers, advertising giant Publicis is pursuing an ambitious global digital ad strategy.
articles.abstract: Hoping to deliver personalized messages to consumers, advertising giant Publicis is pursuing an ambitious global digital ad strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is only a matter of time until nearly all advertisements around the world are digital.

articles.headline: Fearful of Restive Foreign Labor, Dubai Eyes Reforms
articles.snippet: After several years of labor unrest in the United Arab Emirates, the government is seeking peace with the migrant workers who make local citizens a minority.
articles.abstract: After several years of labor unrest in the United Arab Emirates, the government is seeking peace with the migrant workers who make local citizens a minority.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — They still wake before dawn in desert dormitories that pack a dozen men or more to a room. They still pour concrete and tie steel rods in temperatures that top 110 degrees. They still spend years away from families in India and Pakistan to earn about $1 an hour. They remain bonded to employers under terms that critics liken to indentured servitude.

articles.headline: Career Women in Japan Find a Blocked Path
articles.snippet: Despite a law promising equal opportunity, women in Japan have had trouble reaching positions of authority.
articles.abstract: Despite a law promising equal opportunity, women in Japan have had trouble reaching positions of authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Aug. 5 — Yukako Kurose joined the work force in 1986, a year after Japan passed its first equal opportunity law. Like other career-minded young women, she hoped the law would open doors. But her promising career at a department-store corporate office ended 15 years ago when she had a baby.

articles.headline: Mortgage Maze May Increase Foreclosures
articles.snippet: The complex design of mortgage securities is confounding homeowners struggling to avoid defaulting on their loans.
articles.abstract: The complex design of mortgage securities is confounding homeowners struggling to avoid defaulting on their loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2003, Dianne Brimmage refinanced the mortgage on her home in Alton, Ill., to consolidate her car and medical bills. Now, struggling with a much higher interest rate and in foreclosure, she wants to modify the terms of the loan.

articles.headline: Murdoch Gives In, So to Speak
articles.snippet: Traditionally the sandbox of publishers, the editorial pages at The Wall Street Journal won guarantees of independence in Rupert Murdoch’s bargain to win control of Dow Jones.
articles.abstract: Traditionally the sandbox of publishers, the editorial pages at The Wall Street Journal won guarantees of independence in Rupert Murdoch’s bargain to win control of Dow Jones.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the winners in the News Corporation’s purchase of The Wall Street Journal were less obvious than others.

articles.headline: Ex-Home Depot Chief to Take Reins at Chrysler
articles.snippet: Robert L. Nardelli, ousted from Home Depot amid shareholder discontent, has been picked to lead Chrysler by its new owner, Cerberus Capital Management.
articles.abstract: Robert L. Nardelli, ousted from Home Depot amid shareholder discontent, has been picked to lead Chrysler by its new owner, Cerberus Capital Management.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Aug. 5 — Robert L. Nardelli, who was ousted as chief executive of Home Depot amid shareholder discontent this year over his enormous pay package, will soon take on one of the most prominent jobs in corporate America: revitalizing the troubled automaker Chrysler LLC.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: ‘Fake Steve’ Blogger Comes Clean
articles.snippet: An editor at Forbes has been lampooning Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, on a popular blog, “Fake Steve.”
articles.abstract: An editor at Forbes has been lampooning Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, on a popular blog, “Fake Steve.”
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 — For the last 14 months, high-tech insiders have been eating up the work of an anonymous blogger who assumed the persona of Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive and one of the world’s most famous businessmen.

articles.headline: A Top Official at Bear Stearns Ousted
articles.snippet: The crisis in the credit markets has claimed a victim: Warren J. Spector, a co-president at Bear Stearns and a 24-year veteran of the organization.
articles.abstract: The crisis in the credit markets has claimed a victim: Warren J. Spector, a co-president at Bear Stearns and a 24-year veteran of the organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: The crisis in the credit markets finally reached the executive suite of Wall Street firms last week, and the victim was an unexpected one: Warren J. Spector, a co-president at Bear Stearns who some had thought could become the firm’s next chief executive.
